Make an R6 Parameter Set for Distributions

Source: R/ParameterSet.R
ParameterSet.Rd

ParameterSets are passed to a Distribution$new constructor when creating a custom probability distribution that takes parameters.

Constructor Arguments

ArgumentTypeDetails
idcharacterunique one-word identifier.
valuenumericinitial parameter value.
lowernumericminimum value parameter can take.
uppernumericmaximum value parameter can take.
classcharacterparameter class; "numeric" or "integer".
settablelogicalif TRUE the parameter can be updated. See Details.
updateFunc = NULLcharacterstring to be parsed and evaluated as function. See Details.
description = NULLcharacteroptional description of parameter.

Constructor Details

An R6 ParameterSet is required to construct a custom Probability Distribution that takes parameters. This constructor ensures that the correct format of parameters is supplied to the disitribution.

Every argument can either be given as the correct type (as listed above) or as a list of that type. If arguments are provided as a list, then each argument must be of the same length list, with values as NULL where appropriate. See examples for more.

Each parameter requires a unique one-word id that is used to get and set parameters after construction. A settable parameter is one that can be updated after construction of a distribution via $setParameterValue. The Distribution is parameterised by whichever parameters are given as settable. Non-settable parameters are either constant or can be automatically updated if an updateFunc is provided. updateFunc should be provided as a string that could be understood in the body of a function by a Distribution object, i.e. by naming parameters via $getParameterValue, see examples.

Internally after calling $setParameterValue, $update is called to update the value of non-settable functions.

Public Methods

MethodDetails
print()Print ParameterSet as data.frame.
update()Updates unsettable parameters with supplied update functions.
parameters(id, error = "warn")If id given, returns specific parameter. Otherwise returns self.
getParameterValue(id, error = "warn")Returns value of parameter matching gven 'id'.
setParameterValue(lst, error = "warn")Set parameters in list names with respective values. See Details.
rbind()Combine the rows of multiple ParameterSets.
as.data.table()Coerces ParameterSet to data.frame.

Public Method Details

Argument 'error' is passed to stopwarn to determine if the code should break or if a warning should be returned when an error occurs.

setParameterValue takes a named list where the list names, names(lst), should match the parameter IDs and the values, as.numeric(lst), are used to set the corresponding parameter value.

See also

Distribution

Examples

 id = list("prob", "size")
 value = list(0.2, 5)
 support = list(Interval$new(0,1), PosIntegers$new())
 settable = list(TRUE, TRUE)
 description = list("Probability of success",NULL)
 ps = ParameterSet$new(id, value, support, settable,
                       description = description)
 ps$parameters()
#>      id value support settable            description updateFunc
#> 1: prob   0.2   [0:1]     TRUE Probability of success         NA
#> 2: size     5      ℤ+     TRUE                   None         NA
 ps$getParameterValue("prob")
#> [1] 0.2
 ps$getParameterSupport("prob")
#> [1] "[0:1]"


 id = list("rate", "scale")
 value = list(1, 1)
 support = list(PosReals$new(), PosReals$new())
 settable = list(TRUE, FALSE)
 updateFunc = list(NULL, "1/self$getParameterValue('rate')")
 description = list("Arrival rate","Scale parameter")
 ps = ParameterSet$new(id, value, support, settable,
                       updateFunc, description)
 ps$parameters(id = "rate")
#>     id value                  support settable  description updateFunc
#> 1 rate     1 <environment: 0x9651eb0>     TRUE Arrival rate       <NA>
 ps$setParameterValue(list(rate = 2)) # Automatically calls $update
 ps$getParameterValue("scale") # Auto-updated to 1/2
#> [1] 0.5
